children.subject:
Anon OP here, I didn’t even realize that until you posted it... 
I would say 271 pretty much resembles some topics in 126+some topics in 174 while having these topics elaborated in depth?
Another opinion from Anon OP: since Prof. Sinclair have taught these two courses, it might be more direct and efficient to ask him for help?
Follow-up to this. What's the difference between CS 174 and CS 271? Is 271 just supposed to be the grad version of 174?

Thanks Abinav! 
Actually, Prof. Adhikari mentioned the difference between Prob 140 and EE 126 in this post: http://prob140.org/about/
He describes Prob 140 as theoretical probability, EE 126 as applicational probability.
From your answer, I kinda realized that CS 174 is as well a course of combinatorics, so it could be very mathematical in nature, which differs it from EE 126 (also the pseudo code style of CS theory courses) would make it more related to Prob 140 in form).
Oops! “he” here should be corrected as “she”, my pad’s fault...

(Anon OP here, sorry for spamming this much)
Wait a min...I read through the syllabus of CS 271 and Prof. Sinclair mentioned that CS 174 is like a prereq of CS 271. However, he also mentioned that any further questions could be addressed by directly talking to him.
IMO I found materials recommended in CS 271 more specialized in topics and fields.

history.content:
Stat 140, EECS 126, and CS 174 are all different takes of the same class: upper-div probability and statistics. 

Stat 140 (Prob 140) is the most traditional offering and it was designed and frequently taught by the much-loved Professor Adhikari. It's exactly what you suspect a stat class would be about; my friends who've taken it say it's really well run. 


EECS 126 is probability from an engineer's perspective. There's like a 75% content overlap between Stat 140 and EECS 126 but EECS 126 also discusses things like queuing theory, info theory, and Kalman filtering. Whole thing has a signal-processing flavor. I really liked this class when I took it.

CS 174 is the most different since it's from a computer scientist's perspective. It's meant to be taken in reference to 170 and 70, you're looking at probability as a tool to make better algorithms and analyses. You cover things like Lovasz local lemma and Hoeffding-Azuma bound which are very, very relevant in CS theory but not so much for an engineer or statistician.

CS 271 is basically a graduate student's version of 174.

children.subject: Prof. Sinclair mentioned that 174 and 270 are prerequisites of 271 in his syllabus. Yet alternative prerequisites seem to be possible if you talk to him.

The original statement is “ Mathematical maturity, and a solid grasp of undergraduate material on Algorithms and Data Structures, Discrete Probability and Combinatorics.” So 270 may not be needed if you are confident with data structures and algorithms taught in 170. 174 corresponds to “a solid grasp of undergrad material on...Discrete Prob and Combinatorics”.
Would you say 271 requires 174 as a prereq?

history.content:
That may be a weird question but I am wondering the overlapping sections between these two courses. 
And, regardless of practice vs. theory difference, what’s the difference between the topics covered in both classes?
Thanks for any thoughts or advices!
